raw_text:
Wall Street cheers Bush victory
 
 The US stock market has closed higher in response to George W Bush's victory in the presidential elections.
 
 The benchmark Dow Jones share index closed more than 1% higher at 10,137, while the Nasdaq rose 0.9% to 2,004. Many investors believe that Mr Bush's policies are more business-friendly than those of his Democrat challenger, John Kerry. The higher share prices also reflect relief that a clear winner has emerged from what proved to be a tight poll.
 
 Investors had worried that the outcome of the poll would be inconclusive, paving the way for a repeat of the legal wrangling that marred the 2000 election.
 
 The Dow lost 5% of its value in the three weeks immediately after that election, when it was unclear who would occupy the White House. Mr Kerry conceded defeat on Wednesday, abandoning last-ditch hopes of carrying the vote in the swing state of Ohio. "The relief for the markets may be that we have a decision and can move forward," said Tim Ghriskey, chief investment officer of Solaris Asset Management. Some analysts predicted that the jump in share prices would be short-lived, saying investors would quickly focus once again on the health of the US economy. "I would look at the stock market rally for Bush as kind of a one-day event," said Ken Mayland at Clearview Economics. The US' recent economic performance has been mixed, with solid growth offset by disappointingly low job creation figures, and mounting worries over a record budget deficit. Elsewhere in the financial markets on Wednesday, the dollar dipped slightly against the euro and climbed against the yen, while US oil prices closed up $1.26 at $50.88 a barrel in New York. The rise in oil prices partly reflects the view that President Bush is less likely than Mr Kerry to release supplies from the US' strategic oil reserve. Share prices in London, Frankfurt and Paris also closed higher.
 
 Successive polls in the run-up to Tuesday's election had shown the two candidates running neck and neck.
 
 Economic issues, as well as the war in Iraq, were the forefront of the campaign. In key swing states such as Ohio, which has suffered substantial job losses in the past four years, President Bush's handling of the economy became a crucial election issue. Senator Kerry attacked President Bush's economic record during his campaign, hammering home the fact that a net 800,000 jobs were lost during his term in office. President Bush focused on the fact that two million jobs have been created in the past year, claiming that it has vindicated his tax-cutting agenda. As for future policies, both candidates pledged to bring America's $422bn federal budget deficit under control. Senator Kerry planned to increase taxes on those earning more than $200,000 a year. President Bush has placed reform of the pensions system at the heart of his economic agenda for a second term. However, economists have said both candidates' economic programmes rested on questionable assumptions about future growth.
llama3.2:1b: The US stock market closed higher in response to George W Bush's presidential election victory, with the Dow Jones rising 1.1% and the Nasdaq up 0.9%. Investors praised Bush's business-friendly policies, which they believe will lead to economic growth. The outcome of the poll was seen as a relief for investors, who had worried about a repeat of the uncertainty following the 2000 election.
llama3.2:3b: The US stock market closed higher after George W Bush's victory in the presidential election, with the Dow Jones share index rising over 1% and the Nasdaq up 0.9%. Investors welcomed a clear winner and relief that a repeat of the 2000 election's legal wrangling was avoided. Share prices rose in London, Frankfurt, and Paris, while US oil prices closed up $1.26 at $50.88 a barrel.
gemma2:2b: The US stock market surged following George W. Bush's victory in the presidential election. Investors attributed this to expectations of more business-friendly policies and relief over a clear winner emerging from a close contest. Some analysts believe the positive market reaction is temporary and that economic concerns, including job creation and the budget deficit, will dominate investor focus in the near future.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
The US stock market closed higher following Bush's victory in the presidential election. Investors had been concerned about the outcome of the poll, which had raised doubts about who would occupy the White House. Many investors believed that Bush's policies were more business-friendly than those of his Democratic challenger John Kerry. The share prices of many stocks also showed a rise, reflecting relief after the results of the poll. The US economy was experiencing mixed performance with solid growth offset by job losses and rising budget deficits.

The two major candidates running for president were George W. Bush and John F. Kerry. In Ohio, where Senator Kerry had previously won the election, Bush's handling of the economy became a key issue in the election. He focused on the fact that 800, 000 jobs have been lost during his term and claimed that it has vindicated his tax-cutting agenda. President Bush promised to increase taxes on those earning more than $200, 000 per year.

Economists have said that both candidates' economic programmes rested on questionable assumptions about future growth. The Democratic candidate, Kerry, plans to raise taxes on those earning more than $200, 000 a year. Republican candidate Bush has placed reform of the pension system at the heart of his economic agenda for a second term.

Bush wins presidential election, reflecting relief that clear winner has emerged from tight poll and hopes for business-friendly policies.股市因乔治·W·布什赢得总统选举而上涨，反映了选民对明确胜利者的希望以及企业友好政策的期待。许多投资者相信，与民主党对手约翰·克里相比，布什的政策更有利于商业。过去一周内美国经济状况表现不一，包括经济增长和就业不足的问题。在布什的经济记录受到批评的情况下，他的选举优势可能促使市场参与者重新关注经济状况。
qwen2.5:3b: US stock market closed higher in response to George W Bush's victory in presidential elections. Benchmark Dow Jones share index closed 1% higher at 10,137 while Nasdaq rose 0.9% to 2,004. Investors believe Bush policies are more business-friendly than those of Kerry. Share prices also rose due to relief that a clear winner emerged from tight poll outcome. The Dow lost 5% after uncertainty in the election outcome. Analysts predicted short-lived rise in share prices as focus would return to US economy's performance. Oil prices increased slightly with Bush seen as less likely to release strategic oil reserves. Share prices also rose in London, Frankfurt and Paris. Economic issues, including job creation and budget deficit control, were key campaign topics.

smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and to the point, capturing the main ideas and key details of the text. The tone is neutral and informative, avoiding any emotional or persuasive language. The summary conveys the essence of the text without including unnecessary information or analysis.

tinyllama:1.1b: In response to the announcement that US president George W. Bush had been elected, the stock market in the United States rose by more than 1%, with the Dow Jones index closing higher by 1% and the Nasdaq rising 0.9% to 2,004. Investors were relieved that the outcome of the poll was not as uncertain as previously thought, and shares remained steady despite concerns about the economy's health in the wake of the presidential election. The election result saw both candidates commit to reducing the budget deficit by introducing increased taxes for high-income earners, while their economic agendas remained uncertain.

Investors expect further gains in stock prices following Mr. Bush's victory, with hopes for a business-friendly administration compared to that of his Democrat challenger John Kerry. However, both candidates have pledged to bring the US federal budget deficit under control over the next four years.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
The US stock market experienced a significant surge following George W. Bush's presidential victory over John Kerry. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose by more than 1%, closing at 10,137, while the Nasdaq increased by 0.9% to 2,004. Investors anticipated that Bush's pro-business policies would be more advantageous for businesses compared to Kerry's. The market's optimism was driven by relief from a potentially drawn-out election outcome and the clarity of Bush's win in key swing states like Ohio, which had suffered job losses during his term.

However, analysts cautioned that this stock market rally might be short-lived, as investors would soon refocus on the US economy's health, marked by mixed growth and high unemployment rates alongside a massive budget deficit. Economists noted that both candidates' proposed economic plans hinged on questionable future growth projections.

Meanwhile, the dollar slightly weakened against the euro but strengthened against the yen. Oil prices rose to $50.88 per barrel due to investors' expectations of less likely deficit-busting actions by Bush from the strategic oil reserve. International stock markets in London, Frankfurt, and Paris also saw higher closings.

In the campaign, economics and Iraq were dominant issues. Kerry criticized Bush's economic record, citing 800,000 job losses during his tenure. Conversely, Bush highlighted job creation of two million over the past year as evidence of his tax-cutting policy's effectiveness. Both candidates vowed to reduce the $422 billion federal budget deficit, with Kerry proposing tax increases for high earners and Bush focusing on pensions system reform. Despite these differences, economists found flaws in both plans' growth assumptions.
reference: Senator Kerry attacked President Bush's economic record during his campaign, hammering home the fact that a net 800,000 jobs were lost during his term in office.The US stock market has closed higher in response to George W Bush's victory in the presidential elections.The higher share prices also reflect relief that a clear winner has emerged from what proved to be a tight poll.The rise in oil prices partly reflects the view that President Bush is less likely than Mr Kerry to release supplies from the US' strategic oil reserve.In key swing states such as Ohio, which has suffered substantial job losses in the past four years, President Bush's handling of the economy became a crucial election issue.President Bush has placed reform of the pensions system at the heart of his economic agenda for a second term.President Bush focused on the fact that two million jobs have been created in the past year, claiming that it has vindicated his tax-cutting agenda.The US' recent economic performance has been mixed, with solid growth offset by disappointingly low job creation figures, and mounting worries over a record budget deficit.Share prices in London, Frankfurt and Paris also closed higher.Some analysts predicted that the jump in share prices would be short-lived, saying investors would quickly focus once again on the health of the US economy.
